message_1:
One example of a precise numerical problem that a math student can solve within the subject of Cryptography and Substitution ciphers is:

Using a substitution cipher with a key of "LXUGJPSRZYFMHQTVWBCOKEAIND", encrypt the message "SEND ME YOUR ANSWERS" and write down the resulting ciphertext.
message_2:
To encrypt the message "SEND ME YOUR ANSWERS" using the given substitution cipher key, we will replace each letter in the message with the corresponding letter in the key. The key is a rearrangement of the alphabet, so we can use the position of the original letter in the alphabet to find the corresponding letter in the key.

Message: SEND ME YOUR ANSWERS
Alphabet: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

S -> L (19th letter)
E -> X (5th letter)
N -> U (14th letter)
D -> G (4th letter)
(space)
M -> J (13th letter)
E -> X (5th letter)
(space)
Y -> P (25th letter)
O -> S (15th letter)
U -> R (21st letter)
R -> Z (18th letter)
(space)
A -> Y (1st letter)
N -> U (14th letter)
S -> L (19th letter)
W -> W (23rd letter)
E -> X (5th letter)
R -> Z (18th letter)
S -> L (19th letter)

Ciphertext: LXUG JX PSRZ YUWXLWZL

So, the encrypted message is "LXUG JX PSRZ YUWXLWZL".
